sen.j: 桜町天皇（さくらまちてんのう、享保5年1月1日（1720年2月8日） - 寛延3年4月23日（1750年5月28日））は、江戸時代の第115代天皇（在位享保20年3月21日（1735年4月13日） - 延享4年5月2日（1747年6月9日））。
sen.e: Emperor Sakuramachi (February 8th, 1720 - May 28th, 1750) was the 115th Emperor during Edo Period. (his reign was April 13th, 1735 - 9th June, 1747.)
Emperor Sakuramachi (February 8, 1720 - May 28, 1750), the 115th Emperor, reigned during the Edo period (from April 13, 1735 to June 9, 1747).
Emperor Sakuramachi (February 8, 1720 - May 28, 1750), the 115th Emperor, reigned during the Edo period (from April 13, 1735 to June 9, 1747).

sen.j: 幼名を若宮、諱を昭仁（てるひと）という。
sen.e: His name from the childhood was Wakamiya, posthumous name was Teruhito.
His name from childhood was Wakamiya, and his posthumous name was Teruhito.
His name from childhood was Wakamiya, and his personal name was Teruhito.
sen.cmt: いみなをpersonal nameとしました。

sen.j: 享保13年（1728年）に立太子、同20年（1735年）に父帝の譲位により践祚。
sen.e: In 1728 he became Crown Prince and ascended the throne after his father passed the throne to him in 1735.
In 1728 he became the crown prince, and in 1735 he ascended the throne after his father passed it to him.
In 1728 he became the crown prince, and in 1735 he ascended the throne after his father passed it to him.

sen.j: 江戸幕府の征夷大将軍徳川吉宗の助力と関白一条兼香の補佐を得て朝廷の儀式の復古に力を入れ、大嘗祭の再復活や新嘗祭、奉幣使などの他の儀礼の復活にも力を注いだ。
sen.e: He had a help and support from the barbarian-quelling generalissimo, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, and the Chancellor (chief adviser to the emperor), Kaneka ICHIJO, he put efforts into to restore the Imperial Palace events, such as the Great Thanksgiving Service (after the Enthronement of an Emperor), or other events like The Harvest Festival and Hohen shi. (an Imperial messenger to a Shinto shrine)

He had the help and support of the barbarian-quelling generalissimo, Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, and the chancellor (chief adviser to the Emperor), Kaneka ICHIJO, and accordingly he endeavored to restore the events of the Imperial Palace, such as the Great Thanksgiving Service (after the Emperor's enthronement), or other events such as the Harvest Festival and Hohen shi (an imperial messenger to a Shinto shrine).

He had the help and support of the Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians"), Yoshimune TOKUGAWA, and the chancellor (chief adviser to the Emperor), Kaneka ICHIJO, and accordingly he endeavored to restore the events of the Imperial Palace, such as the Great Thanksgiving Service (after the Emperor's enthronement), or other events such as the Harvest Festival and Hohen shi (an imperial messenger to a Shinto shrine).
sen.cmt: "barbarian-quelling generalissimo"→"Seii Taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians")"に変更しました。

sen.j: また、自ら「大日本天皇昭仁親王」と記していることから、朝儀の復興を通して天皇の権威向上に努めていたことが窺える。
sen.e: Also he called himself 'The Great Japan Emperor, Prince Teruhito', it is presumed he tried to improve the status of Emperor by restoring the Court Council.
Additionally, he called himself 'The Great Japanese Emperor, Prince Teruhito,' so it is presumed that he tried to improve the status of the Emperor by restoring the Court Council.
Additionally, he called himself 'The Great Japanese Emperor, Imperial Prince Teruhito,' so it is presumed that he tried to improve the status of the Emperor by restoring the Court Council.
sen.cmt: 親王→Imperial Prince と統一しました。

sen.j: 延享4年（1747年）桃園天皇に譲位して院政を開始するが、寛延3年（1750年）に脚気衝心により31歳で崩御。
sen.e: In 1747 he abdicated and passed the throne to Emperor Momozono, and started cloister government, however he died due to heart failure from beriberi. (1750)
sen.cmt: 院政→cloister government 英二辞郎 on the web
sen.e: In 1747, he abdicated and passed the throne to Emperor Momozono and started a cloister government; however, he died of heart failure due to the beriberi disease (1750).
In 1747, he abdicated and passed the throne to Emperor Momozono and started a cloister government; however, he died of heart failure due to the beriberi disease (1750).

sen.j: なお、徳富蘇峰の『近世日本国民史』以来、天皇が幕府の圧力によって退位したとする説があるが、実際には退位後においても積極的に政治や学問の振興策を主導しており、むしろ幕府からの干渉を避けるために院政による政治運営を行う狙いがあったと考えられている。
sen.e: There is a theory that the Emperor abdicated under the pressure of the government after the issue of "Modern Japanese history" by Soho TOKUTOMI, in fact, it is considered after the abdication he aimed to focus on ruling cloister government without having pressure from the government, by actively controlling to restore politics and studies.

There is a theory that the Emperor abdicated under the pressure of the government after the issuance of "Modern Japanese History," by Soho TOKUTOMI; however, it is considered that after the abdication he aimed to focus on ruling the cloister government without having pressure from the government, doing so by actively controlling the restoration of politics and studies.

There is a theory that the Emperor abdicated under pressure from the government after the publication of "Modern Japanese History," by Soho TOKUTOMI; however, it is considered that after his abdication, he aimed to focus on ruling the cloister government without pressure from the government, doing so by actively promoting political and academic programs.
sen.cmt: 「振興策を主導する」としました。

sen.j: ただ、院政を充実させるには残された3年という期間は余りにも短すぎるものであった。
sen.e: However he only had three years being in power and it was not long enough to rule the cloister government to fulfill his aim.
However, he only had three years in power, which wasn't sufficient to rule the cloister government in fulfillment of his goal.
However, he only had three years in power, which wasn't sufficient to rule the cloister government in fulfillment of his goal.

sen.j: 神沢貞幹の『翁草』によると生まれが元旦でそのとき火事があり且つ実績も立派という共通点から聖徳太子の再来といわれ、歴史家としても知られた公家の柳原紀光も「延喜・天暦の治以来の聖代である」と評したという。
sen.e: According to "Okina gusa" by Tekan KANZAWA, the Emperor was called he was the return of Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku) since they both have similarity like born on the New Year and there was a fire on the day, or they both achieved a lot in the politics, the famous historian from court noble, Motomitsu YANAGIWARA commented the Emperor, 'the Saint Emperor of the peaceful era of Engi and Tenryaku'.
sen.cmt: 聖徳太子→Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku) [英辞郎ON THE WEB]
sen.e: According to "Okina gusa," by Tekan KANZAWA, the Emperor was called the return of Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku), since they had similarities such as a New Year's birthday and there was a fire on the day of birth, or that they both achieved a lot in politics; moreover, the famous historian and court noble, Motomitsu YANAGIWARA, referred to the Emperor as 'the Saint Emperor of the peaceful era of Engi and Tenryaku.'

According to "Okina gusa," by Teikan KANZAWA, the Emperor was called the return of Shotoku Taishi (Prince Shotoku), since they had similarities such as a New Year's birthday and there was a fire on the day of birth, or that they both achieved a lot in politics; moreover, the famous historian and court noble, Motomitsu YANAGIHARA, referred to the Emperor as 'the first Saint Emperor since the peaceful era of Engi and Tenryaku.'
sen.cmt: Teikanとしました 以来の、の意味を出すだめに、the first Saint Emperor since the peaceful era of Engi and Tenryaku としました。Yanagihara としました。

sen.j: 烏丸光栄に古今伝授を受けるなど歌道に優れ、御製は『桜町院御集』や『桜町院坊中御会和歌』としてまとめられている。
sen.e: He learned poems from Mitsuhide KAEASUMARU and he was a talented poet, his poems are edited in "Collection of Tanka Poetry by the ex-Emperor Sakuramachi" and "Sakuramachi in bochu onkai waka".
sen.cmt: 桜町院御集→Collection of Tanka Poetry by the ex-Emperor Sakuramachi [定訳不明] 『桜町院坊中御会和歌』→"Sakuramachi in bochu onkai waka" [定訳不明]
sen.e: He learned poems from Mitsuhide KAEASUMARU and was a talented poet; his poems are edited in "Collection of Tanka Poetry by the ex-Emperor Sakuramachi" and "Sakuramachi in bochu onkai waka."

He was a talented poet as he received teachings of Kokinshu (Collection of Poems Ancient and Modern) from Mitsuhide KARASUMARU; his poems are edited in "Collection of Tanka Poetry by the Retired Emperor Sakuramachi" and "Sakuramachiin bochu onkai waka."
sen.cmt: 古今伝授を受けるなど の訳を入れました。 Ex-Emperor→Retired Emperor Sakuramachiとしました。 KARASUMARUにしました。

sen.j: また曽祖父・霊元天皇の御製を分類して『桃蕊類題（とうずいるいだい）』を残している。
sen.e: Also the Emperor edited and completed his great grandfather's poem collection, "Tozui Ruidai".
Additionally, the Emperor edited and completed his great grandfather's poetry collection, "Tozui Ruidai."
Additionally, the Emperor edited and completed "Tozui Ruidai," the poetry collection of his great grandfather, the Emperor Reigen.
sen.cmt: 霊元天皇を追加しました。

sen.j: 絵画にも優れ、東京国立博物館にある「武者小路実陰肖像画」は重要美術品に指定されている。
sen.e: He was a talented painter as well and his artwork 'Portlate of Sanekaage MUSHANOKOJI' at Tokyo National Museum is stated as an art treasures.
sen.cmt: 東京国立博物館→Tokyo National Museum [www.tnm.go.jp]
sen.e: He was also a talented painter, and his artwork titled 'Portlate of Sanekaage MUSHANOKOJI,' housed at the Tokyo National Museum, is designated as an art treasure.
He was also a talented painter, and his artwork titled 'Portrait of Sanekage MUSHANOKOJI,' housed at the Tokyo National Museum, is designated as an art treasure.
sen.cmt: スペル（portrait, sanekage)修正しました。

sen.e: Kyoho (June 22, 1716 - April 28, 1736)
Kyoho (June 22, 1716 - April 28, 1736)
Kyoho (June 22, 1716 - April 28, 1736)
Genbun (April 28, 1736 - February 27, 1741)
Genbun (April 28, 1736 - February 27, 1741)
Genbun (April 28, 1736 - February 27, 1741)
Enkyo (February 21, 1744 - July 12, 1748)
Enkyo (February 21, 1744 - July 12, 1748)
Enkyo (February 21, 1744 - July 12, 1748)

tit.e: Posthumous name, Tsuigo, a different name
Posthumous name, Tsuigo, a different name

sen.j: 仙洞御所の宮名である桜町殿により桜町院と追号された。
sen.e: The Tsuigo of Sakura in came from Sakuramachi dono, which was the palace of Sento Gosho. (Palace for an ex-Emperor)
The Tsuigo of Sakura-in came from Sakuramachi dono, which was the palace of Sento Gosho (a palace for an ex-Emperor).
The Tsuigo (a posthumous title) of Sakuramachiin came from Sakuramachi dono, which was the palace of Sento Gosho (a palace for an retired emperor).
sen.cmt: Sakuramachiin, retired emperor としました。追号の補足を追加しました。

tit.cmt: 他の記事と統一しました。

sen.j: 京都市東山区今熊野泉山町の月輪陵（つきのわのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed in Tsukino wa no misasagi at Senzan-cho Town, Imagumano, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: 京都市東山区今熊野泉山町→Senzan-cho Town, Imagumano, Higashiyama Ward, Kyoto City [yu-bin.net]
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed in Tsukino wa no misasagi at Senzan-cho Town, Imagumano, in the Higashiyama ward of Kyoto City.
The Emperor was entombed in Tsuki no Wa no Misasagi at Senzan-cho, Imagumano, in the Higashiyama Ward of Kyoto City.
sen.cmt: Tsuki no Wa no Misasagi として統一しました。
